What are the most common symptoms of Crohn's Disease? Crohn's Disease is a chronic autoimmune disorder that causes inflammation in the digestive system. The most common symptoms of Crohn's Disease include: - Abdominal pain and cramping: Patients with Crohn's Disease often experience abdominal pain and cramping, typically in the lower right side of the abdomen. This pain can be severe and can be accompanied by bloating, gas, and a feeling of fullness. - Diarrhea: Diarrhea is a common symptom of Crohn's Disease, as the inflammation in the digestive tract can disrupt the normal movement of food and waste through the body. Diarrhea can be accompanied by urgent bowel movements and the passing of blood or mucus. - Weight loss: Crohn's Disease can cause weight loss due to malabsorption of nutrients from the food we eat, and also from the chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain and lack of appetite that often accompany the disease. - Fatigue: Fatigue is a common symptom of Crohn's Disease, as the body is working hard to fight the inflammation and heal the damaged tissue. The chronic inflammation also causes lack of energy and makes the patient feel tired. - Anemia: Anemia is a common complication of Crohn's Disease, as the inflammation can cause bleeding in the digestive tract, leading to a loss of red blood cells. This can cause symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath. It's worth noting that these symptoms can vary from person to person and may not always be present. In addition, the symptoms may come and go, often referred to as flare-ups or remission. If you suspect you may have Crohn's Disease, it's important to see a doctor for proper diagnosis and treatment. How is Crohn's Disease diagnosed? Crohn's Disease is a complex condition and can be difficult to diagnose. However, there are several steps that can be taken to help identify the condition and confirm a diagnosis. The process of diagnosing Crohn's Disease typically includes a combination of medical history, physical examination, blood tests, imaging tests, and endoscopic procedures. - Medical history and physical examination: The first step in diagnosing Crohn's Disease is taking a thorough medical history and conducting a physical examination. During this process, the doctor will ask about the patient's symptoms, as well as any family history of the condition. The doctor will also perform a physical examination, which may include a rectal exam and a test for tenderness in the abdomen. - Blood tests: Blood tests can be used to help diagnose Crohn's Disease by looking for signs of inflammation and anemia. The doctor may also check for a high white blood cell count, which can indicate an infection or inflammation. - Imaging tests: Imaging tests, such as X-ray, CT scan, or MRI, can be used to view the inside of the gastrointestinal tract and identify any abnormalities, such as inflammation or blockages. These tests can help the doctor determine the location and extent of the inflammation. - Colonoscopy: A colonoscopy is a procedure in which a thin, flexible tube with a camera on the end is inserted into the rectum and used to view the inside of the colon. The procedure can help the doctor identify any abnormalities, such as ulcers or strictures, that may be indicative of Crohn's Disease. - Endoscopy: An endoscopy is a similar procedure to a colonoscopy, but it is used to view the upper gastrointestinal tract, such as the esophagus, stomach, and small intestine. This procedure can also help the doctor identify any abnormalities that may be indicative of Crohn's Disease. It's worth noting that the process of diagnosing Crohn's Disease can take some time and may require multiple tests and procedures.
